data.title: OSX multiple desktop change bug
data.body:
After changing between desktops sometimes Atom freeze. I get "Atom not responding" message, but after rechanging desktops it works again.
- OSX 10.11.2
- Atom 1.4.0

I can't describe how to reproduce the issue, it happens randomly.

data.title: There is obvious delay of response when move focus back to Atom on Windows platform
data.body:
I have tried Atom1.2.4 and 1.4.0, both have this isssue.

I lunched Atom, open a project, open a file or not, then click on any free space of the desktop to make Atom lose the focus, then back to Atom with a click to any part of Atom, the Atom editor cannot response to my mouse click (or keyboard hit) immediately, there is about 3-5 seconds delay. (The Atom window does not freeze, but it just cannot allow me to edit open file immediately)

I am using Windows7 with i5 + 4GB Memory.

data.title: atom version 1.4.0: makedown syntax highlighting issues
data.body:
When the MakedownFile has '\' symbol,
the next row content has problem with syntax highlighting.
For example:

``` makedown
row1 ### output: \*.\*
row2 ### hello
```

Row2 has problem with syntax highlighting.

data.title: Atom can not delete file or directory from left tree
data.body:
System: windows 7
Atom version: 1.4.0

data.title: Ligatures do not work with some programming languages
Atom crashes when opening a file from a git repository which has entry contains a forbidden file name on Windows
data.body:
[Environment]
Windows 8.1 64bit

[Reproduction Steps]
1. Install and run latest atom 1.4.0, no extra package installed.
2. Make sure project folder closed in tree view.
3. Drag a file from network mapped driver or remote shared folder into atom.

[Expected Behavior]
File opened and new project folder created.

[Observed Behavior]
Atom crashed. (screen shot and crash log attached)
[Capture.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/95271/Capture.zip)
[Atom Crashes.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/95272/Atom.Crashes.zip)

[Installed packages]
No extra package, all built-in Atom packages.

[Additional information]
Issue can be reproduced in safe mode.
Issue has a fail rate to happen, but easy to see when directory depth is deep on network location. I suspect it's related to connection timeout or remote path info. cache not ready.

data.title: Atom tries to delete undefined file when no file is selected
data.body: This is Atom 1.4.0 on OS X 10.10.5. Reproduce/What does happen: Select a file in the file tree. Press Fn-Delete; atom will show a delete alert. Click Move to Trash. The once-selected file is deleted and no file is selected. Press Fn-Delete again; atom will show a delete alert but with no file name. Click either Cancel or Move to Trash and the alert will disappear with no effect. What should happen: Not completely sure, but probably the Fn-Delete press should be ignored.

data.title: Can Atom do automatic closing of tags?
data.body:
Either when you type 

```
<script>
```

and then it will immediately become 

```
<script></script>
```

or the other way is, if you have a `<script>`  that is not yet closed yet, and you type

```
</
```

and it will automatically make it `</script>` for you, because it will help you find the closing tag and enter for you.  Adobe Brackets can do this quite well.

data.title: Honor `created()` function for an item in a submenu.
data.body: Fixes #10483.

data.title: Atom: can't delete folder from tree view
data.body: I'm having trouble deleting a folder from the tree view sidebar. I can create a folder but I can't delete it once it's created. I get the "Are you sure...Move to Trash" pop-up but nothing happens when I select "Move to Trash" - Windows 7, Atom 1.4.0

data.title: Honor created() function for an item in a submenu.
data.body: Fixes #10483.

data.title: The created function is not honored for a menu item in a submenu
data.body:
I believe it is due to this code:

https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.4.0/src/context-menu-manager.coffee#L140-L144

Specifically, `Object.create()` is called on a root `item`, is screened for visibility via `shouldDisplay()`, and then its `created()` function is called, if it exists.

Unfortunately, this sequence is not applied recursively for submenu items.

data.title: Closed A Window And a Background Atom Window Closes too
data.body: When does this happen ? Is it a bug ? The font window did not have any unsaved files

data.title: Disposing of commands doesn't remove them from the command palette?
data.body:
Trying to get to the bottom of atom/sort-lines#45, I created the code you can find on the [`ld-dispose-commands` branch of the sort-lines package.](https://github.com/atom/sort-lines/tree/ld-dispose-commands) It seems now that disposed commands don't remove themselves from the Command Palette, so they can perhaps go screwy when a package updates itself while Atom is running.

**Repro Steps**
1. Clone `ld-dispose-commands` branch of sort-lines package
2. Execute `apm link --dev` from sort-lines repo
3. Launch Atom in Dev Mode
4. Open an editor using <kbd>Cmd+N</kbd>
5. Open the Command Palette using <kbd>Shift+Cmd+P</kbd>
6. Type `sort` to bring "Sort Lines: Sort" to the top
7. Close Command Palette with <kbd>Esc</kbd>
8. Open the Settings View with <kbd>Cmd+,</kbd>
9. Click the Packages tab
10. Search for `sort-lines`
11. Click the Disable button
12. Select the tab for the open editor
13. Open the Command Palette using <kbd>Shift+Cmd+P</kbd>
14. Type `sort` to bring "Sort Lines: Sort" to the top

**Expected:** "Sort Lines: Sort" to **not** show up in the list
**Actual:** "Sort Lines: Sort" does show up in the list

Tested on Atom v1.6.0-dev-f826d38 on Mac OS X 10.11.2 and Atom v1.4.0 on Mac OS X 10.11.2.

/cc @atom/feedback

data.title: project folder name, show the project in focus
data.body:
When using the editor with more than 1 project folder added (ex. with "Add Project Folder" mouse menu button at left folder viewer), the first project name is showed at "status" (superior bar)... Even when you nou using any file of the project and with many files of other (ex. second) project files... This make confusion and is not util.

The ideal is to show (at superior status bar) **the project of the _in focus_ file**.

data.title: left in pixelRectForScreenRange of editorElement is 0 when typing in 1.5.0-beta0
data.body: [My package](https://github.com/tony612/highlight-column) had a problem when I upgraded to 1.5.0-beta0 that the highlight bar will bounce to first column when I'm typing like this(it should be always at the position the cursor is at): When I looked into this problem, I changed some of my code to below for debugging, which will be called in `cursor.onDidChangePosition`'s callback. ``` coffeescript _cursorPixelRect: -> {row, column} = @cursor.getScreenPosition() console.log "Row ", row, "Col ", column screenRange = new Range(new Point(row, column), new Point(row, column + 1)) rect = @editorElement.pixelRectForScreenRange(screenRange) console.log "pixelRangeForScreenRange ", @editorElement.pixelRangeForScreenRange(screenRange) console.log "pixelRectForScreenRange", rect rect ``` Then I got the log like this: It seems the results of `editorElement.pixelRectForScreenRange` and `editorElement.pixelRangeForScreenRange` didn't match. And it should be zero because column is not zero, right? So, is this a bug for `pixelRectForScreenRange` or my own problem?

data.title: Unsaved buffers aren't restored if there is no project folder added to the window
data.body:
According to this [release notes for 1.4.0beta](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases/tag/v1.4.0-beta0) and this [issue report](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/942) Atom is supposed to automatically save any unsaved/untitled buffer upon closing.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open Atom.
2. Open a new tab
3. write something without saving it
4. close atom (click X or file->exit)
5. reopen atom
6. the unsaved new untitled tab is missing. It should be there with all the content that you wrote.

This is important feature for me, please fix it. Thanks.

data.title: Path in Window title stays the same and is wrong
data.body:
In the window title after the filename (that is being separated by a dash) there is the file path, but for some reason sometimes it doesn't get updated when you change tabs or open a new tab. This results in displaying an incorrect path which can lead to serious problems (I won't go there, it is obvious).

Example:

![atom-window-title-path-bug 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5416165/12388742/78061346-bddd-11e5-888e-32d61555fdfd.PNG)

When opening atom and open a file it correctly displays the filename and then the correct path besides it.

![atom-window-title-path-bug 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5416165/12388743/780981e8-bddd-11e5-8959-5bbb26b61ab5.PNG)

But if then you open or switch to a new tab the path remains the same and is therefore incorrect.

Atom 1.4.0
Windows 10 x64

data.title: Atom crashes on startup with certain git repository
data.body:
Atom crashes on startup with the message "The editor has crashed" when opening a certain repository. 

Some information:
- The OS is Windows 7
- This crash occurs with the latest Atom version as well as 1.5.0-beta0
- The crash occurs in normal and safe mode
- I was able to reproduce the issue by creating a new folder, cloning the repo
  (https://github.com/TerriaJS/terriajs) and launching atom with `atom --safe terriajs/`

data.title: Fix 64-bit Windows builds
data.body:
Fixes #10450.

It turned out to be a combination of a couple things: I accidentally broke it in the async-git branch, but we were also missing one 32-bit override.

data.title: Shouldn't the package changelog be taken from GitHub?
data.body: Currently, there's a big `CHANGELOG` which shows up if your package contains a file called `CHANGELOG.md`. But since GitHub already has the [Releases](https://github.com/atom/atom/releases) feature (which easily allows devs to add the changes to each version), I was wondering why we're not leveraging this instead? If you ask me, the changelog should simply be generated from the existing changelog in the "Releases" section of each repo. :innocent:

data.title: Atom starts with the same files every time, instead of the last files i had open
data.body: For some reason atom opens two specific unrelated files every time i start it. one of them doesnt even exist anymore. How can i solve this for now?
